conclusion: To determine the resistance R_L of the coil L, analyze the behavior of the circuit when the switch S is opened at t_1 = 1.0 × 10^{-3} s.
Before opening the switch, the circuit is in a steady state.
The total resistance in the circuit is R_total = R + R_L = 2.0 Ω + R_L.
The current through the circuit is given by Ohm's law: I_steady = U / R_total = 6.0 V / (2.0 Ω + R_L).
When the switch is opened, the current through the circuit starts to decay due to the inductive effect of the coil L.
The circuit now consists of the inductor L and the resistor R in series.
The current through the circuit decays exponentially with time according to the equation: I(t) = I_steady e^{-t/τ}, where τ is the time constant of the circuit.
The time constant τ is given by τ = L / R.
From the graph (Figure B), the current I(t) decays to approximately half its initial value at t = 1.0 × 10^{-3} s.
This corresponds to I(1.0 × 10^{-3} s) = I_steady / 2.
Substitute I(1.0 × 10^{-3} s) = I_steady / 2 into the exponential decay equation: I_steady / 2 = I_steady e^{-1.0 × 10^{-3} s/τ}.
Take the natural logarithm of both sides: ln(1/2) = -1.0 × 10^{-3} s/τ.
Relate time constant to inductance: τ = L / R.
